Title: Lurk in Darkness, Hunt Down Shadows
SubTitle: No Translation

Text: Now then...

(I may have distanced myself from Alexandria and
Mitsugoshi, but my work is the same, essentially.)

(I lurk in the darkness, investigate shadows, and
sometimes hunt them down.)
(That's all that's left for me to do now.)

The fairy tale is over...or something along
those lines.

(I'll be lucky if I can find anything just by sneaking into
a pharmacy.)

(That said, I must be crazy for taking on an
investigation that's likely to be a
waste of time.)

(Yeah, it's not something I'd usually do. Maybe I'm
suffering from some mental trauma after all.)

(...I'm sure Lady Alpha would laugh and tell me it's
essential to investigate even the most trivial leads.)

(Yes, even the most trivial of leads can lead to
something big. Wasn't that what Eta said?)
Eta, are you done analyzing the drug?
...Are you sleeping?
I'm awake...and I'm done...

Well then, will you let me hear your analysis and
findings?
Are you answering or falling asleep?
Mm...both.
I thought as much. So, what's it looking like?

...The drug I analyzed is made from a chemical
compound that completely erases all traces of
magic...

This drug...is regularly sold over-the-counter.
It's expensive...and not very popular.

I know about drugs that enhance magic traces, but
it's the first I'm hearing about a drug that erases
them.

If magic took place, it's only natural that it should
leave behind magic traces, even if it's impossible
to identify the individual who performed it...

If the traces were to vanish completely, it would
appear unnatural and make it evident that
something happened there.

In other words, it would be difficult to use it to
erase evidence of a crime.

...But if you narrow down its uses...it could be...
pretty effective.

For example...it could be used to clean up the rooms
of mansions belonging to aristocrats and luxury
hotels on the market...

And...it can be used overtly, as the Templars use it,
to erase all magic traces from an attack.
...It could also erase traces of the possessed.

Some aristocrats might consider using...
this medicine...if a possessed showed up
among their own.
So, it'd be a good place...to start investigating...

The desire to go to such lengths to render a
possessed as if they had never existed...
is truly irredeemable.

...But the premise is, as a rule, "possession"
doesn't occur in humans in the first place.

In the past six months, the Shadow Garden has
sheltered more than eighty of the possessed,
all girls who were either elves or therianthropes.

The only human possessed we know of is Lady Claire,
and she is an exception to the rule.

Indeed... How interesting... If Master Shadow would
permit it, I'd like to use her as a test subject...
I'm pretty sure you'd get scolded for that.
Just getting scolded...would be a cheap price to pay!
C'mon, don't get any ideas.

(...That intel Eta provided me with before I left
about the drug which removes the magic traces...)

(Well, the fact is that it's not widely available,
so it may potentially lead somewhere.)
Alright, time to start investigating.

(There's nothing suspicious about the pharmacy
itself.)

(Still, the inventory of the drug in question has
shifted drastically in the past two weeks.)

(The Marquez family, an aristocratic family of the
Midgar Kingdom, has purchased large quantities
of the drug.)

(A prestigious family that has produced gifted dark
knights generation after generation, particularly well-
known in the fields of interrogation and espionage.)

(The impression on the side of the pharmacy who
sold the drugs was that its intended use was to
erase evidence of an affair.)

(In fact, due to its ability to erase magic traces,
it is said to often be used for such purposes...)

...Or has the Marquez family recently become backers
of the Templars' activities in Midgar Kingdom?

But if that's the case, there wouldn't be a need to
suddenly purchase large quantities of the drug
necessary for their activities from a regular
pharmacy...

...Are they doing this intentionally to throw off any
indications of ties to the Church?

(In any case, I've decided where I'll start my
investigation. What will I ultimately uncover
about the Marquez family?)

(...If they really are just hiding evidence of an
affair, I guess that means I've lost my touch.)
...Well, there's no harm in investigating.
